text.b: DESCRIPTION OF PROJECT AND ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING

page.text: The purpose of the project is to provide a public park with a play
field within the unincorporated community of Pajaro. There are currently no public parks or
recreational facilities in the community. While public parks exist across the Pajaro River in the City
of Watsonville in Santa Cruz County, this is outside the jurisdictional boundary of the County of
Monterey. Additionally, the Pajaro River and levee physically separate the two communities, and
Pajaro residents look largely to the County of Monterey to address their recreation needs.
Pajaro is a largely low income Hispanic farm worker community with a large number of youth, and
soccer is the most popular recreational activity. No formal soccer playfields are present either in
Pajaro or in the parks identified in Watsonville within a half mile of the community. In general, the
community currently lacks sufficient community amenities, such as open space, parks, civic facilities
and community services to accommodate the growing needs of the relatively young population of
Pajaro (Source IX.4). According to the County’s Five Year Redevelopment Implementation Plan for
the area, 10 acres of recreation/park space with at least one baseball/softball diamond, two soccer
fields and some playgrounds and tot lots are required for a community the size of Pajaro. Currently
the Pajaro Middle School, located at 250 Salinas Road approximately ½ mile from the project site,
provides limited recreational facilities in the area (Ibid.).
Due to this lack of recreational facilities for the existing population, several potential park sites have
been identified in previous planning efforts undertaken by the Monterey County Redevelopment
and Housing Office. In order to facilitate park construction, the Redevelopment Agency set aside
$449,000 in its five‐year implementation plan from 2005 to 2010.
The proposed Pajaro Neighborhood Park site is located within the unincorporated
community of Pajaro in the northwestern portion of Monterey County adjacent to the Pajaro River.
Pajaro is adjacent to and south of the City of Watsonville in Santa Cruz County (see Figure 1). The
project site is located off of San Juan Road, west of its intersection with Porter Drive.
. The proposed project consists of property acquisition by Monterey
County and development of a community park to serve the unincorporated community of Pajaro.
The proposed park will serve approximately 3,500 residents in the community of Pajaro and
surrounding areas and will be the community’s first park.

text.i: Facilities.

page.text: The proposed park will consist of new facilities including:
• Recreational play facilities to include:
A turf field for youth size baseball and soccer with a baseball backstop
A decomposed granite running track
A full‐size basketball court
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 3
INITIAL STUDY
• Playgrounds:
One playground for 5‐12 year‐olds
One playground for 2‐5 year‐olds separated and surrounded by seatwalls for parents
to sit on and supervise their children
• Accessory Recreational Facilities:
A small stage area for local celebrations and displays
Picnic areas with tables and benches
Three shade pavilions with barbecue facilities that can be rented out to groups to
generate revenue for the park
• Other Facilities:
A pre‐fabricated restroom building
Drinking fountains
• Parking: An asphalt parking lot with 53 parking stalls and a vehicular drop‐off area
Approximately 42% of the site will consist of the turf field. The remainder of the site will consist of
decomposed granite, asphalt, concrete, natural open space that can be used for dog
walking/running, and shrub and groundcover landscaping. A small turf area will run alongside the
baseball diamond to provide seating and lounging opportunities for baseball spectators. [A
conceptual site plan is shown on Figure 2.
The turf sports field will be either synthetic turf material or natural grass. Determination of the turf
material will be made after the project grant funding has been finalized, which is estimated to occur
in December of 2009. The field will be designed to accommodate both options of the synthetic or
natural grass material. The synthetic turf installation will require specific design for site runoff and
soil subgrade treatment. The Redevelopment Agency intends to apply for a grant from the
Statewide Park Development and Community Revitalization Act of 2008 (Proposition 84) to fund
the design and construction of the project. If funding is not granted in December 2010, it is
anticipated that the play field will initially be planted with turf grass. However, the County intends
to convert the field to synthetic turf at such time that funding becomes available.
An existing 3,500 square‐foot rectangular galvanized metal building along the southern property
line will be retained. It is intended that a portion of the building may eventually serve as a meeting
room for local Boy Scout troops or other community group, and the other portion will serve as
equipment and machinery storage. However, the building will not be modified as part of this
project.

text.i: Operations.

page.text: The park is intended for use by the residents of the community of Pajaro for team
sports, primarily soccer and baseball, children’s playground, picnicking, parties, barbecues, and
other general local‐serving recreational needs. The park is expected to be open to the public during
daylight hours only, and locked by maintenance personnel during the night.
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 4
INITIAL STUDY
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 5
INITIAL STUDY
The park will be secured with perimeter fencing, security lighting, and lockable vehicular and
pedestrian gates in response to concerns expressed by the Pajaro Citizens Advisory Sub‐Committee
(CAC) and residents living adjacent to the park site regarding the high number of homeless
transients living in the riverbed adjacent to the site. Night‐time lighting will be minimal and only
for security purposes.
Primary vehicular and pedestrian access to the park will be from San Juan Road. Emergency
vehicular and secondary pedestrian access will be at the southeast corner of the site off Florence
Avenue, through the adjacent neighborhood.

text.i: Utilities.

page.text: New electricity, water, and plumbing facilities will be brought on the site to the new
restroom building and shade pavilions. A new storm drainage system will be installed throughout
the site. All utility lines can be accessed through Florence Avenue at the southeast corner of the site
through an eight‐inch water line, an eight‐inch sanitary sewer line, and a twelve‐inch storm drain
line.
Phasing.
The park will be constructed in two phases, depending on available funding. Phase 1 will
consist of construction of all underground utilities, the turf field, and gravel parking lot. Phase 2 will
consist of construction of all other park components listed above, including paving the gravel
parking lot. The turf field may be converted to synthetic turf in Phase 2 if not installed in Phase 1.
Lot Merge.
The project site currently consists of three contiguous Assessors’ Parcels. It is proposed
that the project entitlement process will include filing a Reversion to Acreage map to merge these
parcels into a single parcel.

text.b: Environmental Setting and Surrounding Land Uses

page.text: The project 4.9‐acre site is located in the northwestern portion of the unincorporated community of
Pajaro adjacent to the Pajaro River, which forms the boundary between Monterey and Santa Cruz
counties. The city of Watsonville in Santa Cruz County is located north of the project site and the
Pajaro River.
The site is located off of San Juan Road west of its intersection with Porter Drive. Vehicular access to
the site is provided via San Juan Road through a County‐owned easement (APN 117‐341‐099‐000) at
the project entrance. The site is bordered by the Pajaro River and its levee to the north/northwest,
residential development to the east and south, and the Southern Pacific Railroad tracks and
agricultural land uses to the west. A levee access easement exists over APN 117‐331‐025 off San
Juan Road in favor of the County Water Resources Agency. The Union Pacific railroad right‐of‐way,
a separate fee‐owned property, abuts the property on the south. There are no easements on the site
related to the railroad.
The project site is currently vacant, but was the former location of the Granite Construction
Company corporation yard. The site was formerly used as a construction company office,
construction staging and mobilization facility, and equipment and materials storage yard. The
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 6
INITIAL STUDY
former main building has been demolished and onsite soils were remediated in 2009. There is an
existing 3,500 square‐foot rectangular galvanized metal building on a concrete slab foundation on
the site along the southern property line that will be retained. A rusted, corrugated metal fence
currently separates the site from neighboring homes along the northeast boundary. A concrete
retaining/screen wall separates the site from neighboring homes along the southeast boundary.
The property is relatively flat and is devoid of trees or significant vegetation, except for scattered
non‐native grasses and weeds. Two Monterey pine trees are located on the Pajaro River levee
immediately adjacent to and north of the site.
The community of Pajaro covers approximately 243 acres including roadways. The community
consists of primarily high‐density residential development interspersed with commercial and
industrial uses. The surrounding area consists of mixed residential and commercial uses in the
community of Pajaro. A single‐family residential neighborhood is located adjacent to the site on the
east and south, and commercial uses are found further east along Porter Drive.
Pajaro is a small community surrounded by prime agricultural lands currently in cultivation, and
lands to the west of the project site in strawberry cultivation. The community and surrounding areas
are located within the 100‐year flood plain of the Pajaro River. To the northwest across the Pajaro
River, within the Watsonville City Limits, are industrial properties, and to the southwest are
agricultural fields.
The Monterey County actions that are covered in this Initial Study include:
acting as the Board of Directors of the
Redevelopment Agency of the County of Monterey: Approval of property acquisition for
development of a park by the Redevelopment Agency.

consisting of:

Zoning variance to potentially permit an increase in fence height and a possible

text.b: III. PROJECT CONSISTENCY WITH OTHER APPLICABLE LOCAL
AND STATE PLANS AND MANDATED LAWS

page.text: Use the list below to indicate plans applicable to the project and verify their consistency or non-
consistency with project implementation.
General Plan/Area Plan
Air Quality Mgmt. Plan
Specific Plan
Airport Land Use Plans
Water Quality Control Plan
Local Coastal Program-LUP
The project is designated Residential‐High Density 8 DU/Ac in the
Monterey County General Plan. The County is in the process of updating its General Plan. A draft
General Plan Update and Final EIR have been prepared. It is expected that the General Plan Update
will be considered by the Board of Supervisors in early 2010. Existing Monterey County zoning for
the site is HDR/B‐6 – High Density Residential with a “Building Site” designation of B‐6. The “B”
districts establish specific regulations for lot size and structure setbacks; the B‐6 designation limits
further subdivisions on a given property and establishes setbacks for structures. Parks are allowed
in this zone district per Monterey County Code Title 21, section 21.10.050.D., subject to approval of a
conditional use permit from the Planning Commission. Review of project consistency with existing
General Plan policies and relevant policies proposed in the draft General Plan Update will be
provided in the EIR that will be prepared for the project.
The Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District’s
(MBUAPCD) 2008 Air Quality Management Plan For the Monterey Bay Region (AQMP) addresses state
air quality standards. The Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District (MBUAPCD)
incorporates the regional population forecasts prepared by the Association of Monterey Bay Area
Governments (AMBAG) in its preparation of regional air quality plans. Population‐generating
projects that are within the AQMP population forecasts are considered consistent with the plan. The
proposed project is a park project that will not result in construction of new housing or an increase
in population. Thus, the project is in conformance with the AQMP.

for adverse environmental impact related to most of the topics in the Environmental Checklist;
and/or potential impacts may involve only a few limited subject areas. These types of projects are
generally minor in scope, located in a non‐sensitive environment, and are easily identifiable and
without public controversy. For the environmental issue areas where there is no potential for
significant environmental impact (and not checked above), the following finding can be made using
the project description, environmental setting, or other information as supporting evidence.

EVIDENCE:
The proposed project would not result in structural development, and site is not
located with a public scenic viewshed. There are no scenic resources on the site. Thus, the
project would not result in impacts to scenic views or scenic resources. .
The project site is not designated for agricultural use in the
Monterey County General Plan or State Farmland Mapping system nor is it zoned for
agricultural use. The proposed project will not result in conversion of agricultural lands or
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 10
INITIAL STUDY
conflicts with agricultural zone designations. Agricultural lands are found to the west of the
site, but the proposed park site is separated from adjacent agricultural lands by a 100‐foot
railroad right‐of‐way, which borders the site and entire western side of the community of
Pajaro. Development of a park would not adversely affect adjacent agricultural properties as
it would not result in potential conflicts with adjacent agricultural uses that could indirectly
lead to conversion of adjacent farmland to non‐agricultural uses. Similarly, adjacent
agricultural land uses would not conflict with the proposed park. The railroad right‐of‐way
provides a 100‐foot buffer between the site and adjacent agricultural lands. The project will
not result in new habitable structures. Therefore, no impacts would be expected to occur
related to indirect impacts on existing agricultural uses.
The property supports scattered patches of ruderal, non‐native
vegetation. The site is disturbed having been the former location of a corporation yard, and
more recently was excavated to implement soil remediation efforts. There are only scattered
patches of weedy grasses and shrubs on the site with no native vegetation or habitat present.
There are no trees on the property. The site has been heavily disturbed, and the property
provides little habitat for wildlife due to the sparseness of the vegetation and the compacted
and disturbed condition of the ground. A biotic assessment prepared for the project found
no evidence of federally listed or state‐listed plant or wildlife species, habitat to support
such species or other sensitive habitats (Source IX.8 – Biotic Resources Group, October 2009),
and thus, the project would result in no impacts to special status species, riparian habitat,
wetlands or other sensitive habitat areas. The site is bordered by developed uses to the east
and south and cultivated agricultural land to the west in an area that is partially developed
and has been disturbed. The area is not expected to be used as a wildlife movement area due
to the lack of suitable natural habitat areas in the area. There are no trees on the project site
that would be could be used by nesting raptors. Therefore, no impacts are expected related to
wildlife movement or nesting. There are no known Habitat Conservation Plan or Natural
Community Conservation Plans in the area. Therefore, the project would result in no impact
related to potential conflicts with these type of plans.
The proposed park will not result in creation of risks
associated with hazardous material use as no hazardous materials would be used. The
project site was owned and used by Granite Construction Company for a business office,
industrial storage yard, and heavy equipment repair over the past 40 years and similar uses
have been operated on the property since 1940. Soil contamination was previously
identified on the site, and remediation (scraping, excavation, and removal of shallow
impacted soils at the site to approximately 12‐15‐inches below grade) was performed to a
level that meets or exceeds State and County standards for residential development. On
June 9, 2009, the Monterey County Health Department Environmental Health Division
issued a letter concluding that the existing shallow soil contamination has been remediated,
a recently discovered monitoring well was properly destroyed, and that therefore no further
action is required to mitigate soil contamination at the site (Source IX.6 – Monterey County
Department of Health, June 2009).
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 11
INITIAL STUDY
The project site is not included on a state list of hazardous materials sites (compiled
pursuant to Government Code Section 65962.5). The Watsonville Municipal Airport is
located approximately 1.5 miles north of the proposed Pajaro Neighborhood Park site. There
are no private airstrips in the area that would be affected by the proposed project. As a
community park, the project would not interfere with implementation of the County’s
emergency plan. The project site is located within a developed area surrounded by
agricultural lands except for the city of Watsonville to the north. The project site is not in an
area exposed to wildland fire hazards due to absence of dense vegetation and steep terrain.
The proposed park project would not result in habitable structures or an increase in
population. Therefore, no impacts are expected related to hazards or hazardous materials.
No mineral resources exist in the project area. Therefore, no impact is
expected as a result of the project.
The proposed project consists of development of a community
park and will not result in new housing or population increases.
The project sites do not
contain habitable structures. The project, therefore, would not displace numbers of people or
homes or otherwise adversely affect housing or population. Therefore, there is no impact
related to population and housing.
The proposed project will provide a community park for the residents of Pajaro
and will not result in new development, population or public service demands related to
parks and recreational facilities. Thus, the project would result in no impacts to parks or
recreational facilities.
Pajaro Neighborhood Park

A brief explanation is required for all answers except “No Impact” answers that are
adequately supported by the information sources a lead agency cites in parentheses
following each question. A “No Impact” answer is adequately supported if the referenced
information sources show that the impact simply does not apply to projects like the one
involved (e.g., the project falls outside a fault rupture zone). A “No Impact” answer
should be explained when it is based on project-specific factors as well as general
standards (e.g., the project will not expose sensitive receptors to pollutants, based on
project-specific screening analysis).
All answers must take into account the whole action involved, including offsite as well as
onsite, cumulative as well as project-level, indirect as well as direct, and construction as
well as operational impacts.
Once the lead agency has determined that a particular physical impact may occur, then
the checklist answers must indicate whether the impact is potentially significant, less
than significant with mitigation, or less than significant. "Potentially Significant Impact" is
appropriate if there is substantial evidence that an effect may be significant. If there are
one or more "Potentially Significant Impact" entries when the determination is made, an
EIR is required.
"Negative Declaration: Less Than Significant With Mitigation Incorporated" applies when
incorporation of mitigation measures has reduced an effect from "Potentially Significant
Impact" to a "Less Than Significant Impact." The lead agency must describe the
mitigation measures, and briefly explain how they reduce the effect to a less-than-
significant level; mitigation measures from "Earlier Analyses" (see below), may be
cross-referenced.
Earlier analyses may be used when, pursuant to the tiering, program EIR or other CEQA
process, an effect has been adequately analyzed in an earlier EIR or negative
declaration. Section 15063(c)(3)(D). In this case, a brief discussion should identify the
following:
a)
Earlier Analysis Used. Identify and state where they are available for review.
b)
Impacts Adequately Addressed. Identify which effects from the above checklist
were within the scope of and adequately analyzed in an earlier document
pursuant to applicable legal standards, and state whether such effects were
addressed by mitigation measures based on the earlier analysis.
c)
Mitigation Measures. For effects that are "Less than Significant with Mitigation
Measures Incorporated," describe the mitigation measures which were
incorporated or refined from the earlier document and the extent to which they
address site-specific conditions for the project.
Lead agencies are encouraged to incorporate into the checklist references to information
sources for potential impacts (e.g., general plans, zoning ordinances). Reference to
previously prepared or outside documents should, where appropriate, include a
reference to the page or pages where the statement is substantiated.

text.i: a-b) Scenic Views and Scenic Resources – No Impact.

page.text: The project site is located in the northwestern
corner of the community of Pajaro. The site is visible only from the adjacent residential
neighborhood to the east and south. The Pajaro River levee on the north blocks views into the site
from areas north of the site. There are no designated scenic roads in the area. Furthermore, the site is
not visible from other nearby streets and is not part of a scenic view or public viewshed. Based on
field observations, there are no scenic resources on the project site. The site does not contain trees or
support other physical features that would be considered scenic. Therefore, no impact is expected
related to scenic views or scenic resources as none exist on the project site or vicinity.

text.i: c) Effects on Surrounding Visual Character – Less than Significant.

page.text: The project is located at the
northwestern edge of the developed community of Pajaro. Residential uses are found to the east
and south of the south and are characterized by older, single‐family homes. Mixed commercial uses
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 15
INITIAL STUDY
are found along Porter Drive further east of the site. Open agricultural fields border the site and
community of Pajaro on the west.
The project will not result in development of new structures, and thus there would no issues related
to compatibility of building mass and scale with adjacent areas. Fencing is planned around the
perimeter of the park for security reasons. A specific design has not yet been developed, although a
12‐foot height has been discussed. It is the intent to develop a design to address security concerns at
night, while being attractively designed. Although, the impact is expected to be less‐than‐significant,
potential aesthetic impacts on the neighborhood will be reviewed in the EIR.

text.i: d) Light and Glare – Less than Significant.

page.text: The proposed park will open for daytime use. No
nighttime lighting of play fields is proposed. It is the intent to install lighting for security purposes
around the site, but lighting will not be installed in a manner that would result in offsite glare into
adjacent residences. Although, the impact is expected to be less‐than‐significant, potential lighting
impacts on the neighborhood will be reviewed in the EIR.
In determining whether impacts to agricultural resources are significant environmental effects, lead
agencies may refer to the California Agricultural Land Evaluation and Site Assessment Model (1997)
prepared by the California Dept. of Conservation as an optional model to use in assessing impacts on
agriculture and farmland.

text.i: a-b) Agricultural Land Conversion – No Impact.

page.text: The project site is not designated for agricultural
use in the Monterey County General Plan nor is it zoned for agricultural uses, although agricultural
lands are found to the west of the site. The site is not subject to a Williamson Act contract. The site is
not designated as prime, unique or other farmland in the State Farmland Mapping system (FMMP).
The FMMP, operated by the California Department of Conservation, produces maps and statistical
data used for analyzing impacts on California’s agricultural resources. Agricultural land is rated
according to soil quality and irrigation status; the best quality land is called Prime Farmland. The
maps are updated every two years with the use of a computer mapping system, aerial imagery,
public review, and field reconnaissance. The project site and the entire community of Pajaro are
designated “Urban and Built‐up Land” in the State’s Farmland Mapping System (Source IX.9 ‐
California Department of Conservation, 2006). Therefore, the proposed project will not result in
conversion of agricultural lands or conflicts with agricultural zone designations, and would result in
no impact.

text.i: b-c) Effects on Surrounding Agricultural Lands Conversion – Less than Significant.

page.text: The proposed park
site is separated from adjacent agricultural lands by a 100‐foot railroad right‐of‐way, which borders
the site and entire western side of the community of Pajaro. The lands to the west of the project site
are designated “Farmlands” in the Monterey County General Plan. Adjacent agricultural lands are
designated as Prime Farmlands in California’s State Farmland Mapping System.
Development of a park would not adversely affect adjacent agricultural properties as it would not
result in potential conflicts with adjacent agricultural uses that could indirectly lead to conversion of
adjacent farmland to non‐agricultural uses. Similarly, adjacent agricultural land uses would not
conflict with the proposed park. The railroad right‐of‐way provides a 100‐foot buffer between the
site and adjacent agricultural lands. Agricultural operations can generate dust and noise and
pesticide application is regulated by state law to prevent any offsite movement. Exposure to
agricultural operations would be temporary for park users, but the project will not result in
structural development or a permanent residential population. Therefore, no impacts would be
expected to occur related to indirect impacts on existing agricultural uses.
Appendix G of the State CEQA Guidelines (Environmental Checklist) does not currently include
forest lands. However, proposed changes to the Guidelines that are expected to be in effect in
January 2010 include consideration of forest lands as part of the agricultural resources question. The
proposed changes include new checklist questions as to whether a proposed project would conflict
with existing zoning for, or cause rezoning of, forest land (as defined in Public Resources Code
section 12220(g)) or timberland (as defined in Public Resources Code section 4526) or whether the
project would result in the loss of forest land or conversion of forest land to non‐forest use. Because
of the proposed changes, a discussion is included in this EIR. The site is located in an area
characterized by agricultural uses and there are no timber resources on the site or in the
surrounding area.

text.i: a) Conformance with Air Quality Plan – No Impact.

page.text: The Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control
District’s (MBUAPCD) 2008 Air Quality Management Plan For the Monterey Bay Region (AQMP)
addresses state air quality standards. The Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District
(MBUAPCD) incorporates the regional population forecasts prepared by the Association of
Monterey Bay Area Governments (AMBAG) in its preparation of regional air quality plans.
Population‐generating projects that are within the AQMP population forecasts are considered
consistent with the plan. The proposed project is development of a community park, which will not
result in a population increase. Thus, the project does not conflict with or obstruct implementation
of the AQMP.

text.i: b,e) Project Emissions – Less than Significant Impact.

page.text: To protect public health, both the U.S.
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Resources Board (CARB) have
established ambient air quality standards (AAQS) that are the maximum levels of ambient
(background) air pollutants considered safe, with an adequate margin of safety to protect public
health and welfare. The national standards address six criteria pollutants, including ozone, carbon
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 18
INITIAL STUDY
monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide, fine particulate matter (both PM
and PM
, which refer
to particles less than 10 microns and 2.5 microns, respectively), and lead. The state standards, which
are generally more stringent than the federal standards, apply to the same pollutants as the federal
standards do, but also include sulfate, hydrogen sulfide, and vinyl chloride.
The project site is located within the North Central Coast Air Basin as established by CARB, which is
under the jurisdiction of the Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District (MBUAPCD) and
includes Santa Cruz, Monterey and San Benito Counties. The NCCAB is currently in attainment for
the federal PM
(particulates less than 10 microns in diameter) standards and state and federal
nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide and carbon monoxide standards. The basin is considered
attainment or unclassified for other national standards and non‐attainment for the state PM
standard, non‐attainment transitional for the 1‐hour component of the state ozone standard, and
non‐attainment for the 8‐hour component of the state ozone standard.
The proposed park project components will not result in permanent stationary emissions. Sensitive
receptors in the vicinity of the project site include the residential neighborhood to the south and
east. However, the proposed project would not result in stationary emissions that would expose
residents to substantial pollution concentrations. The proposed use would generate some traffic, but
would limited as the proposed facility would likely be accessed via walking or bicycling from the
Pajaro neighborhoods. Thus, the project is not expected to result in indirect vehicular emissions that
would result in an air quality violation, and this is considered a less‐than‐significant impact.

text.i: d,e) Construction Impacts – Less than Significant.

page.text: The site is relatively flat, but will require regrading
to create the proposed playing field and potentially for drainage. Project grading could result in a
short‐term, localized decrease in air quality due to generation of particulate emissions (PM
) caused
by clearing, excavation, and grading operations. According to MBUAPCD’s “CEQA Air Quality
Guidelines” (as updated in February 2008), 8.1 acres could be graded per day with minimal
earthmoving, or 2.2 acres per day with major grading and excavation without exceeding the
MBUAPCD’s PM
threshold of 82 lbs/day. The project site totals 4.9 acres and with minimal
grading would be below the Air District’s threshold for potentially significant impacts. Additionally,
the entire site would not be graded, only the area for the playing field and improvements, and
grading would not be completed in one day. It is likely that grading would span a couple of weeks,
and, thus, daily grading would be below MBUAPCD thresholds.
Therefore, the project would result in a less‐than‐significant impact related to construction emissions
as no significant dust generation or PM
emissions impacts would occur with project grading.
However, dust‐suppression practices should be implemented to avoid nuisance impacts to adjacent
residents, and the following Condition of Approval is recommended.
Require implementation of “Best
Management” construction practices to control dust and PM
emissions during
grading and site development. The MBUAPCD identifies the following construction
practices to control dust:
• Water all active construction areas at least twice daily;
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 19
INITIAL STUDY
• Prohibit all grading activities during periods of high winds (over 15
mph);
• Cover all trucks hauling dirt, sand or loose materials.
• Cover or water stockpiles of debris, soil and other materials which can
become windblown;
• Install wheel washers at the entrance to construction sites for all existing
trucks;
• Sweep streets if visible soil material is carried out from the construction
site;
• Apply chemical soil stabilizers on inactive construction sites;
• Plant vegetative ground cover in disturbed areas as soon as possible.
Sensitive receptors in the vicinity of the project site include the residential neighborhood to the
south and east. Diesel particulate matter was identified as a toxic air contaminant (TAC) by the state
of California in 1998. Following the identification of diesel as a TAC, the California Air Resources
Board (ARB) developed a comprehensive strategy to control diesel PM emissions. The “Risk
Reduction Plan to Reduce Particulate Matter Emissions from Diesel‐Fueled Engines and Vehicles”—
a document approved by ARB in September 2000—set goals to reduce diesel PM emissions in
California by 75% by 2010 and 85% by 2020. This objective would be achieved by a combination of
approaches (including emission regulations for new diesel engines and low sulfur fuel program). An
important part of the Diesel Risk Reduction Plan is a series of measures for various categories of in‐
use on‐ and off‐road diesel engines, which are generally based on the following types of controls:
Retrofitting engines with emission control systems, such as diesel particulate filters or
oxidation catalysts,
Replacement of existing engines with new technology diesel engines or natural gas engines,
and
Restrictions placed on the operation of existing equipment.
Once the Diesel Risk Reduction Plan was adopted, the ARB started developing emission regulations
for a number of categories of in‐use diesel vehicles and equipment. In July 2007, the ARB adopted
regulations for in‐use, off‐road diesel vehicles that will significantly reduce particulate matter
emissions by requiring fleet owners to accelerate turnover to cleaner engines and install exhaust
retrofits.
Project grading and could involve the use of diesel trucks and equipment that will emit diesel
exhaust, including diesel particulate matter. Although there are existing residences adjacent to the
project site, construction‐related diesel emissions would be of limited duration (i.e., during grading)
and temporary, and , and thus, the project would not expose sensitive receptors to substantial
pollutant concentrations. Furthermore, the State is implementing emission standards for different
classes of on‐ and off‐road diesel vehicles and equipment. Therefore, this is considered a less‐than‐
significant impact.
Pajaro Neighborhood Park

text.i: c) Cumulative Emissions – No Impact

page.text: . According to the MBUAPCD CEQA Guidelines, projects that
are consistent with the Air Quality Management Plan (AQMP) would not result in cumulative
impacts, as regional emissions have been factored into the Plan. The MBUAPCD prepares air quality
plans which address attainment of the state and federal emission standards. These plans
accommodate growth by projecting growth in emissions based on different indicators. For example,
population forecasts adopted by Association of Monterey Bay Area Governments (AMBAG) are
used to forecast population‐related emissions. These forecasts then are accommodated within the
AQMP. As indicated above, the proposed park project will not result in new population growth,
and thus would not conflict with the adopted Air Quality Management Plan for the region.
Furthermore, in light of the increasing importance of the issue of global climate change,
consideration was given to whether the project would cause significant new emissions of
greenhouse gases. Based on the data presented above, the project would not cause a new significant
project effect due to the fact that it will not result in stationary emissions nor result in population
growth that would generate indirect emissions.

text.i: f) Odors – No Impact.

page.text: The proposed park would not create objectionable odors as none of the
component park elements are known for generating odors. Therefore, no impacts related to
generation of odors are expected to occur.

The property supports scattered patches of ruderal vegetation. This herbaceous vegetation type is
comprised of weedy, non‐native plant species, typical to previously disturbed areas. The site is
disturbed having been the former location of a corporation yard. More recently the site was
excavated to implement soil remediation efforts. There are only scattered patches of weedy grasses
and shrubs on the site with no native vegetation or habitat present. There are no trees on the
property. Two Monterey pine trees are located on the levee, but would not be affected by the
proposed development. The site has been heavily disturbed, and the property provides little habitat
for wildlife due to the sparseness of the vegetation and the compacted and disturbed condition of
the ground. The presence of base rock intermixed with the soil also moderates the site’s value to
wildlife (Source IX.8 – Biotic Resources Group, October 2009).

text.i: a) Special Status Species – No Impact.

page.text: A biotic assessment prepared for the project found no
evidence of federally listed or state‐listed plant species or habitat to support such species (Source
IX.8 – Biotic Resources Group, October 2009). Although special status wildlife species are known to
occur in the greater project vicinity (i.e., California red‐legged frog, Santa Cruz long‐toed
salamander), no special status species were observed or are believed to have the potential to occur
within the proposed project site due to the very disturbed nature of the property (i.e., previous
building site, construction yard, and soil remediation activities) and the limited vegetative cover
(Ibid.). Therefore, the project would result in no impact to special status species.

text.i: b-c) Riparian and Wetland Habitat – No Impact.

page.text: Vegetation and habitat areas on and/or adjacent to
the project sites include non‐native grassland/ruderal (weedy) areas, agricultural lands. The site is
bordered by developed uses to the east and south and cultivated agricultural land to the west. The
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 22
INITIAL STUDY
property was not observed to support any sensitive plant communities (Source IX.8 – Biotic
Resources Group, October 2009).
The Pajaro River and its levee border the site on the north. The property is located southeast of the
Pajaro River levee, and this section of the Pajaro River supports only scattered riparian vegetation
(i.e., scattered cottonwoods trees). Most of the river corridor adjacent to the proposed park supports
grassy, herbaceous vegetation. The proposed park is located approximately 375 feet from the
centerline of the river and approximately 140 feet from the closest trees that comprise the river’s
riparian corridor (Source IX.8 – Biotic Resources Group, October 2009). The proposed park is
separated from the river environs by an unvegetated river levee. As no night‐lighting is proposed
for the park, no significant indirect impacts to the riparian resources along the Pajaro River are
anticipated from the project (Ibid.). Thus, the project would result in no impacts to riparian, wetland
or other sensitive habitat areas.

text.i: d) Wildlife Corridors and Nesting Species – No Impact.

page.text: The site is bordered by developed uses to
the east and south and cultivated agricultural land to the west in an area that is partially developed
and has been disturbed. The area is not expected to be used as a wildlife movement area due to the
lack of suitable natural habitat areas in the area. There are no trees on the project site that would be
could be used by nesting raptors. Therefore, no impacts are expected related to wildlife movement or
nesting.

text.i: e-f) Habitat Plans – No Impact.

page.text: There are no known Habitat Conservation Plan or Natural
Community Conservation Plans in the area. Therefore, the project would result in no impact related
to potential conflicts with these type of plans.

text.i: a) Historical Resources – No Impact.

page.text: There is one existing structure on the project site – a 3,500
square‐foot rectangular galvanized metal building along the southern property line. The building,
located on the southern portion of the site, appears to be characteristic of older storage areas
associated with industrial uses. It is not known whether the building would be considered a
historical resource, but the building is planned to be retained and potentially incorporated into
future park uses. Therefore, the project would result in no impact to historical resources.

text.i: b) Archaeological Resources – Less than Significant

page.text: . The project site is located within an
archaeological sensitivity area as shown on Monterey County General Plan maps. An archaeological
analysis of the project site was conducted and found that no recorded archaeological sites are
located within one kilometer of the project area (Source IX.7 – Archaeological Consulting, March
1996). During the field reconnaissance, none of the materials frequently associated with prehistoric
cultural resources in this area (shell fragments, dark soil, broken or fire‐altered rocks, bone or bone
fragments, flaked or ground stone, etc.) were observed on the site.
Based on the results of the archaeological investigation and surface reconnaissance, it was
concluded that the project area does not contain surface evidence of potentially significant cultural
resources (Source IX.7 ‐ Archaeological Consulting, March 1996). Furthermore, the site has been
heavily disturbed due to past uses and recent soil remediation activities. However, because of the
possibility of unidentified (e.g., buried) cultural resources being found during construction, it was
recommended that a project condition be included in the event that unknown resources are
discovered during construction. This is considered a less‐than‐significant impact.

text.i: If archaeological resources or human remains are
accidentally discovered during construction, excavation shall be halted within 50 meters (150
feet) of the find until it can be evaluated by a qualified professional archaeologist. If the find is
determined to be significant, appropriate mitigation measures shall be formulated and imple‐
mented. If human remains are discovered during the construction of the project, an
appropriate representative of Native American groups and the County Coroner shall be
informed and consulted, as required by law.
c) Paleontological Resources – No Impact.

page.text: No unique geologic or paleontological features have been
identified in county plans and none were observed on the project sites during site visits. Therefore,
the project would result in no impact to these resources.

text.i: d) Human Remains – No Impact

page.text: . The site has been disturbed, and no known burial sites were
identified in the archaeological review. In the event that human remains are discovered during
project activities, compliance with Section 7050.5 of the State Health and Safety Code and section
5097.98 of the State Public Resources Code would reduce any potential impacts to less than
significant. This is included in the recommendation above.

text.i: a-i, iv) Fault Rupture & Landslides – No Impact.

page.text: The project site is located approximately 7.5 miles
from the active San Andreas Fault zone, and 3 miles from the active Zayante‐Vergales fault zone
(Source IX.10 – D&M Consulting Engineers, June 2005). No mapped faults or fault traces cross the
project sites (Ibid.). The project sites are flat and not within an area of steep slopes subject landslide
hazards. Therefore, no impacts are expected to occur related to fault rupture or landslides.
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 25
INITIAL STUDY

text.i: a-ii-iii) Seismic Shaking and Liquefaction – Less than Significant.

page.text: Seismic shaking is expected as a
result of a major earthquake on regional faults. However, the proposed project elements do not
include habitable structures. A small pre‐fabricated restroom building will be installed according to
California Building Code requirements. Onsite soils generally consist of unconsolidated alluvial and
fill soils that are susceptible to liquefaction.
The property experienced liquefaction‐induced ground failure as a result of the 1989 Loma Prieta
earthquake, although the buildings existing at the time suffered very little damage (Source IX.13 –
Terratech, September 1994). The site experienced about 1 meter of lateral spreading, and both
ground cracking and sand boils occurred at the site (Ibid.).
The alluvial soils underlying the surficial fill soils typically consist of soft to firm sandy silt to a
depth of 16 to 20 feet; the sandy soils were typically loose to medium dense to a depth of 61 feet
(Source IX.10 – D&M Consulting Engineers, June 2005). Subsurface soils borings found that the
upper 15 to 2 feet beneath the site appears to be composed of interbedded loose/soft silt and clay,
which appear to be underlain by loose, fine‐grained, poorly graded sand which varies in thickness
from about 13 to 25 feet (Source IX.13 – Terratech, September 1994). This sand is underlain by
interbedded sand and clay; groundwater was encountered at a depth of about 17 feet beneath the
ground surface (Ibid.). Liquefiable sand layers appear to exist within the sand interval which is
present at depths generally below 20 feet at the site (Ibid.).
A liquefaction analysis was conducted for the project site in 2005. Potential problems associated
with liquefaction at the site include foundation bearing failure, damaging structural or area site
settlements and slope instability or lateral spreading towards the Pajaro River (Source IX.10 – D&M
Consulting Engineers, June 2005). Lateral spreading occurs when large sections of ground move
laterally towards an open face such as a river bank as a result of liquefaction. Horizontal
displacement from lateral spreading was estimated on the order of 3 to 16 feet at the project site
(Ibid.).
Because the project does not propose habitable structures that would be subject to foundation
bearing failure, it is expected that liquefaction hazards would not pose a significant impact to a park
facility. Lateral spreading could displace sections of natural or synthetic turf or other onsite facilities.
However, permanent habitable structures would not be affected as none are proposed. Therefore,
less‐than‐significant impacts are expected to occur related to seismic shaking and liquefaction.

text.i: b) Erosion – Less than Significant.

page.text: The onsite soils are classified as Mocho silt loam in the Monterey
Soil Survey; erosion. Construction activities associated with the project would include site
preparation, grading and installation of utilities. The proposed project would be required to comply
with the Grading Ordinance (Chapter 16.08 of the Monterey County Code) and Erosion Control
Ordinance (Chapter 16.12 of the Monterey County Code). The anticipated impacts from erosion
would be low with implementation of the standard erosion control measures required under these
ordinances to control erosion during construction activities. Therefore, less‐than‐significant impacts
are anticipated related to soil erosion. However, indirect impacts to water quality could result from
inadvertent transport of sediments into nearby water bodies during construction, which is discussed
below in subsection 8(f).
Pajaro Neighborhood Park

text.i: c) Geologic Hazards – No impact.

page.text: The project site is not located on a geologic unit or soil that is
unstable, or that would become unstable as a result of the project (see Items a‐iii and a‐iv above);
therefore, no impacts are expected to occur.

text.i: d) Expansive Soils – Less than Significant.

page.text: The onsite soils are classified as Mocho silt loam in the
Monterey Soil Survey, which are characterized as having a moderate shrink‐swell potential. Because
the project does not propose habitable structures that would be subject to foundation failure, it is
expected that shrink‐swell soil properties would not pose a significant impact to a park facility.
Therefore, this is considered a less‐than‐significant impact.

text.i: e) Soil Suitability – No Impact.

page.text: The project does not involve the use of septic tanks or alternative
wastewater disposal systems; therefore, there is no impact.

text.i: a) Handling Hazardous Materials – No Impact.

page.text: The proposed park will not result in creation of
risks associated with hazardous material use as no hazardous materials would be used. Thus, there
will be no impact.

text.i: b-c) Creation of Hazards – No Impact

page.text: . The project site was owned and used by Granite
Construction Company for a business office, industrial storage yard, and heavy equipment repair
over the past 40 years and similar uses have been operated on the property since 1940. The existing
office building and portion of the existing equipment shed were demolished and removed in 2009.
Three above‐ground fuel storage tanks (ASTs) and one underground storage tank (UST) were
removed from the site in 1996. Soil contamination was previously identified on the site, and
remediation (scraping, excavation, and removal of shallow impacted soils at the site to
approximately 12‐15‐inches below grade) was performed to a level that meets or exceeds State and
County standards for residential development.
On June 9, 2009, the Monterey County Health Department Environmental Health Division issued a
letter concluding that the existing shallow soil contamination has been remediated, a recently
discovered monitoring well was properly destroyed, and that therefore no further action is required
to mitigate soil contamination at the site (Source IX.6 – Monterey County Department of Health,
June 2009). Thus, the project would result in no impact related to exposure to hazardous materials.

text.i: d) Hazardous Sites – No Impact.

page.text: Review of applicable state and Environmental Protection Agency
(EPA) database resources indicate that the project site is not included on a list of hazardous
materials sites (compiled pursuant to Government Code Section 65962.5) which includes but is not
limited to the National Priorities List (NPL) or “Superfund List” and the Comprehensive
Pajaro Neighborhood Park

Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Information System (CERCLIS). Therefore,
the project would not pose a significant hazard to the public or the environment and there would be

page.text: The Watsonville Municipal Airport is located approximately 1.5
miles north of the proposed Pajaro Neighborhood Park site. There are no private airstrips in the area
that would be affected by the proposed project. Additionally, the proposed project consists of park
project and would not result in habitable structures or an increase in population. Therefore, no

text.i: g) Emergency Response Plans – No Impact.

page.text: The Monterey County Emergency Plan contains policies
and actions needed to respond to widespread emergencies. As a community park, the project would
not interfere with implementation of the plan or its objectives; therefore, no impacts would result.

surrounded by agricultural lands except for the city of Watsonville to the north. The project site is

The proposed park project would not result in habitable structures or an increase in population.
Therefore, no impacts are expected.

text.i: a) Waste Discharge – No Impact.

page.text: The proposed park project would not result in discharges that
would be regulated or potentially violate water quality standards or waste discharge requirements.
Therefore, no impacts are expected.

text.i: b) Groundwater - Potentially Significant.

page.text: The project site is located in the Pajaro Valley groundwater
basin, where shallow groundwater flows northwest into the Pajaro River bed. The groundwater
basin has been determined to be in overdraft, which is a primary issue related to any new
development in the area. Water supply for the project will be supplied by the Pajaro Sunny Mesa
Community Services District, whose water supplies are derived from the Pajaro Valley groundwater
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 30
INITIAL STUDY
basin. Project water demand and effects on regional groundwater will be evaluated in an EIR. See
also subsection 16(d) below.

text.i: c) Alteration of Drainage and Erosion Potential – No Impact.

page.text: The proposed project will be connected
to existing storm drains and would have no effect on streams or watercourses in the vicinity.
Therefore, the project would result in no impact regarding alteration of drainage patterns and
watercourses, e.g., the Pajaro River and potential subsequent erosion.

text.i: d-e) Drainage – Potentially Significant.

page.text: The majority of storm‐related surface runoff on the site
currently flows northwest to an existing twelve‐inch culvert under the levee into the Pajaro River.
There is an existing municipal storm drain system adjacent to the property in San Juan Road at
Brooklyn Street. It is anticipated that the project will be graded to drain and connect to that system.
Immediately following the 1995 flood, the Monterey County Redevelopment Agency, in cooperation
with the Monterey County Department of Public Works, prepared and adopted the Pajaro Master
Drainage Plan, and storm drain improvements have been completed. These storm water system
improvements were constructed in four phases, and were designed to handle a 10‐year frequency
storm. Runoff from the 25‐year frequency storm is stored and conveyed away from the community,
thereby minimizing inundation of private property or damage to public facilities (Source IX.5).
Approximately 25% of the site will consist of impervious surfaces, and the proposed soccer field
may be constructed with synthetic turf that would increase impervious surfacing on the site. Further
assessment of project runoff and drainage facilities will be provided in the EIR. The analysis will
also review surface and subsurface drainage issues and potential impacts related to installation of
synthetic turf.

text.i: f) Water Quality – Less than Significant with Mitigation.

page.text: The project site is located adjacent to the
Pajaro River separated from the watercourse by an existing levee. It is anticipated that the project
site will be graded to drain into a municipal storm drain system southeast of the site. However,
runoff may also enter the Pajaro River. Although separated by the levee from the river, site grading
could result in inadvertent erosion into the Pajaro River if not properly managed. Further review of
water quality and erosion impacts will be included in the EIR. The project will be required to
comply with the County’s Grading and Erosion Control Ordinances.

text.i: g-i) Flood Hazard Areas – Less than Significant Impact.

page.text: The project site is located in the 100‐year
floodplain of the Pajaro River as is the surrounding area and community of Pajaro. The levee is the
only separation between the site and the river. The project does not include construction of housing,
and thus would not result in placement of housing within a 100‐year flood hazard area. It is not
expected that the project would result in significant impacts related to flooding, but a flood analysis
will the included in the EIR based on the FEMA FIRM for the area, as well as previous work done as
a result of the 1995 Pajaro River flood event, will be reviewed. While no new buildings other than a
small restroom are being considered for this project, the inclusion of fencing and grading must be
examined to determine whether there would be impacts to adjoining properties. The project site is
not located within an area subject to flooding as a result of failure of a dam as none exist in the area.
However, the site is located adjacent to the Pajaro River levees, which are subject to failure.
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 31
INITIAL STUDY
Consideration of levee failure along the project boundary and its impact to facilities must also be
considered in the floodplain analysis.

text.i: j) Tsunami, Seiche, Mudflow Hazards – No Impact.

page.text: T
he project site is not located in the coastal zone
or near any waterbody, and thus, is not subject inundation by seiche, tsunami, or mudflow.
Therefore, there is no impact.

text.i: a) Physically Divide a Community – No Impact.

page.text: The project is a park project that would be located
within an existing small, developed community of Pajaro. It will provide a lacking public facility
within the community and is adjacent to existing residential areas. As such, it would not divide an
established community and no impact would result with implementation of the proposed project.

text.i: b) Conflicts with Policies & Regulations – Potentially Significant.

page.text: The project is designated
Residential‐High Density 8 DU/Ac in the Monterey County General Plan. Existing Monterey County
zoning for the site is HDR/B‐6 – High Density Residential with a “Building Site” designation of B‐6.
Parks are allowed in this zone district per Monterey County Code Title 21, section 21.10.050.D.,
subject to approval of a conditional use permit. The “B” districts establish specific regulations for lot
size and structure setbacks; the B‐6 designation limits further subdivisions on a given property and
establishes setbacks for structures. The project does not propose additional subdivision of land, but
rather, proposes merging three existing lots to form the proposed park site. As discussed in this
Initial Study, an EIR will be prepared to further assess impacts related to drainage, flood hazards,
water quality, water supply, wastewater service, traffic, and aesthetics. Thus, a review of project
consistency with County General Plan policies will be provided in the EIR once the additional
analyses are complete.
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 32
INITIAL STUDY

text.i: c) Habitat Plans – No Impact.

page.text: Monterey County does not have an adopted Habitat Conservation
Plan, Natural Community Conservation Plan or other approved local, regional or state habitat
conservation plan. Therefore, there is no impact.

text.i: a-b) Noise Exposure – No Impact.

page.text: The project consists of development of a community park
adjacent to a primarily residential area. Lands to the west are in strawberry production, and thus,
the project site may be subject to intermittent equipment noise from adjacent operations. However,
there are no major stationary sources of noise and highly traveled roads or freeways adjacent to the
site that would expose people to substantial noise levels. Therefore, the project would result in no
impact related to noise exposure.

text.i: c) Permanent Noise Increases – Less than Significant.

page.text: The proposed project consists of a park. The
project would have intermittent periods of outdoor sound levels associated with recreational uses.
Peak park use, when soccer games may be played, is expected on weekends and holidays and at
some times after school. The park will be open only during daylight hours. While some residents
may hear intermittent sounds associated with recreational play fields, it would not be of the level or
magnitude that would increase ambient noise levels. Additionally, a solid wall will be provided at
the property line to provide a buffer to adjacent residences. Therefore, the project would result in a
less‐than‐significant impact related to permanent ambient noise levels.

text.i: d) Temporary Noise Increases – Less than Significant.

page.text: Park development and construction will
temporarily increase noise levels in the immediate vicinity Noise levels will vary during the
construction period, depending on the activity and type of equipment used, but would not be
considered substantial due to the short‐term duration and lack of sensitive receptors adjacent to
most of the project sites. Short‐term construction activities will be required to conform to County of
Monterey Noise Ordinances and limited hours of construction. Additionally, a trailer‐mounted,
portable engine generator is included in the project to provide emergency stand‐by power during
times of power outages that could result in periods of increased noise. However, usage would be
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 34
INITIAL STUDY
infrequent and intermittent, except for monthly maintenance in which the units are run for about 30
minutes twice a month. Therefore, the project would result in a less‐than‐significant impact related to
temporary noise levels.

text.i: e-f) Airport Noise – No Impact.

page.text: There are no air carrier or general aviation airports in the vicinity of
the project site. The nearest airport, the Watsonville Airport, is located slightly more than 1.5 miles
north of the proposed project site. The project site is not located within an airport clear zone, which
is located within the immediate airport vicinity. There are no private airstrips in the area that would
be affected by the proposed project. Therefore, no impacts are expected.

text.i: a, c-e) Public Service Demand – No Impact.

page.text: Fire protection services in the project area provided by
the North Monterey County Fire Protection District. The project would not result in structural
development or create fire hazards. The proposed project consists of development of a community
park and will not result in new housing or population increases, and thus, will not result in a
demand for or impact on fire protection, schools or parks. Thus, no impacts are expected related to
these public services. The project will provide a much needed park/recreational facility for the
Pajaro community

text.i: b) Public Service Demand – Less than Significant Impact.

page.text: The Monterey County Sheriff provides
police protection to the project area. The Sheriffʹs Office in Salinas is the departmentʹs primary
dispatching station and houses the administrative and support staff. Patrols in Pajaro are
dispatched from the Sheriff’s Department. The Sheriff’s Department maintains field offices in the
communities of Pajaro and Castroville. The Sheriff’s Department has a mutual aid agreement with
the City of Watsonville Police Department for assistance in the community of Pajaro. The California
Highway Patrol provides traffic law enforcement on County roads, including the streets in the
communities of Pajaro and Castroville.
The Pajaro River channel and levee adjacent to the project site have long been the frequented by
significant numbers of transient and homeless people. Trespassing and vandalism on the project
site have historically been chronic and on‐going problems. There may be an incremental demand for
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 36
INITIAL STUDY
police services, but it would not be of magnitude that would require construction of new facilities
that would result in significant impacts. Furthermore, the project proposes security fencing and
light to prevent trespassing and potential illegal uses on the site at night. Therefore, there would be a
less‐than‐significant impact on police services as a result of the proposed project.

park for the residents of Pajaro and will not result in new development, population or public service

parks or recreational facilities.

text.i: a-b) Traffic – Less than Significant Impact.

page.text: Access to Pajaro is provided by two major roadway
facilities: State Route 1 and U.S. Highway 101, located approximately 10 miles to the east. Both
Route 1 and Highway 101 serve Pajaro from the San Francisco Bay area and other points north and
from Monterey and Salinas and other points south. Route 1, located approximately 2 miles to the
west, is a major regional roadway facility providing access from areas both north and south of
Pajaro. Access to the site is provided via San Juan Road west of its intersection with Porter Drive.
The proposed project is a community park, which will not result in new habitable development or
population increases. A community park to serve local residents would not be expected to result in
significant trip generation that would affect vicinity intersection service levels. However, the EIR
will provide a review of project traffic impacts. It is expected that the park traffic will be local and
typically not during the peak hour periods. For this reason, the scope of work includes the nearby
Porter Drive / San Juan Road and Porter Drive / Bishop Street intersections, as well as, the proposed
project access point unless otherwise requested by Monterey County.
Existing access and road conditions will be described based on existing data. The traffic analysis will
include updated traffic counts at the Main Street / San Juan Road and Porter Drive / Bishop Street
intersections. Project‐related trip generation and distribution will be identified and evaluated for
impacts on street capacities, intersection levels of service, and access and circulation design. Project
parking demand and any onsite provision of project parking also will be reviewed in this
evaluation. Pedestrian access in the vicinity will be reviewed, and any appropriate pedestrian
improvements will be recommended, if needed. Cumulative impacts will be analyzed based on the
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 38
INITIAL STUDY
list of cumulative projects developed in consultation with Monterey County and city of Watsonville
regarding cumulative projects in the area.

text.i: c-e) Air Traffic and Access – No Impact.

page.text: The proposed project will have no effect on air traffic
patterns. Vehicle access will be provided via existing roads, and the proposed water systems
improvements will not increase hazards or result in inadequate emergency access. There would be
no impact.

text.i: f) Parking -- No Impact.

page.text: The proposed project includes a parking lot for 53 spaces. The Monterey
County Zoning Ordinance does not have a specific parking rate for a park use. Although, it is not
expected that parking will be an issue, project parking will be further reviewed in the EIR.

text.i: g) Alternative Transportation – No Impact.

page.text: The proposed park is not expected to result in a level of
increased that would not conflict with adopted policies, plans or programs supporting alternative
transportation. Therefore, there would be no impact.

text.i: a) Wastewater Treatment Requirements – No Impact.

page.text: The proposed park project would not result in
discharges that would be regulated or potentially violate water quality standards or waste discharge
requirements. Therefore, no impacts are expected.

text.i: b,e) Wastewater Treatment – Less than Significant Impact.

page.text: T
he wastewater collection system in the
community of Pajaro is owned and operated by the Pajaro County Sanitation District (PCSD), which
is managed by the Monterey County Public Works Department. The sewer collection system in the
community consists of a looped system. An existing 8‐inch sewer line is located southeast of the
project site off of Florence Avenue, to which project sewer lines would be connected to serve a small
bathroom facility.
The PCSD collects and conveys wastewater to the City of Watsonville Wastewater Treatment
Facility (WWTF) pursuant to its has a contract with the City of Watsonville for treatment. The City’s
wastewater treatment plant is located off of Beach Street west of Watsonville and provides service to
a 21‐square mile area encompassing the City of Watsonville, Freedom County Sanitation District,
Pajaro County Sanitation District, and Salsipuedes Sanitary District. The PCSD through an
agreement with the City of Watsonville, dated May 1, 2001, has capacity rights in the wastewater
treatment facilities for 1.57 million gallons/day (mgd) of flow with specified levels of suspended
solids and biochemical oxygen demand (Source IX.5 ‐ Monterey County Redevelopment and
Housing Office, May 2005).
Previous studies have indicated that there is sufficient treatment capacity to serve the residential
and commercial usage proposed by the “Pajaro Development Support Plan” ‐ Monterey County
Redevelopment and Housing Office, May 2005). It appears that adequate sewer line and
wastewater treatment capacity exists to serve the proposed project, which result in limited
wastewater generation from the onsite bathroom. However, this will be further reviewed and
addressed in the EIR.

text.i: c) Storm Drainage Facilities – No Impact.

page.text: See subsection 8(d‐e) above.
Pajaro Neighborhood Park
Page 40
INITIAL STUDY

text.i: d) Water Supply – Potentially Significant.

page.text: The project site is located within the Pajaro Valley
groundwater basin, which is currently determined to be in overdraft condition and experiencing
seawater intrusion, and any increased demand may be considered potentially significant. The basin
is managed by the Pajaro Valley Water Management Agency. Domestic water service will be
provided to the site by Pajaro Sunny Mesa Community Services District, whose water sources are
from the Pajaro Valley groundwater basin. Further review of project water demand and impacts to
the service provider and regional groundwater condition will be assessed in the EIR. The EIR water
use analyses will assess two scenarios: (1) a “worst case” scenario in which the turf field is planted
with natural vegetation requiring irrigation and (2) a second scenario in which the turf field uses
artificial turf requiring less irrigation. Project water demand rates will be developed in consultation
with PVWMA staff, Redevelopment staff, and the project landscape architect. Project demand will
be compared to available supplies and assessed for impacts on the water supplier capacity and on
the regional overdraft condition. The assessment will be prepared in consultation with agency staff.
f-g) Solid Waste – Less than Significant Impact.
Solid waste in Pajaro is collected by Waste
Management, Inc., a private collection company, under contract with Monterey County, and
transported to the Marina Landfill for disposal. The Marina Landfill has a remaining capacity until
2107 according to information provided in the EIR for the County’s General Plan update.
The
proposed park would result in very limited waste generation, and with sufficient remaining landfill
capacity, the project would result in a less‐than‐significant impact on solid waste systems.
NOTE: If there are significant environmental impacts which cannot be mitigated and no feasible
project alternatives are available, then complete the mandatory findings of significance and
attach to this initial study as an appendix. This is the first step for starting the environmental
impact report (EIR) process.

text.i: a) Degradation of Environment – No Impact.

page.text: Based upon the findings of this environmental initial
study, the proposed project would not significantly degrade or diminish the quality of the
environment, substantially reduce or burden the habitat of fish or wildlife species, cause fish or
wildlife populations to decrease below self‐sustaining levels, threaten to eliminate special or unique
plant or animal communities, or reduce the number or restrict the habitat or range of rare or
endangered plants or animal life. No biological or cultural resources were identified in the area, and
the project would not eliminate important examples of the major periods of California history or
prehistory.

text.i: b) Cumulative Impacts – Potentially Significant.

page.text: The EIR will provide a review of cumulative
impacts and significant cumulative impacts to which the project’s incremental effect may be
cumulatively considerable. Monterey County and City of Watsonville will be contacted to identify
cumulative projects in the area. Cumulative impacts to be addressed include, but are not limited to,
hydrology, traffic, water supply, and global climate change.

text.i: c) Adverse Effects on Human Beings – No Impact.

page.text: The project would not directly or indirectly cause
substantial adverse effects on human beings. The project would provide a needed public park in the
Pajaro community.

* Issues to be addressed in EIR include:
